newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistani rupee seen weak amid rising inflation.
newsitem.headline: Pakistani rupee seen weak amid rising inflation.

text.p: Pakistan's central bank announced a slight rupee depreciation against the dollar on Tuesday and analysts said further adjustments were likely to close an inflation differential with major trading partners.
The State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) moved the rupee down to 40.3300/40.5317 to the dollar from 40.2400/40.4412 fixed on April 23, when it depreciated the rupee by 0.29 percent.
The April adjustment followed a six-month period when the rate remained unchanged. The rupee was devalued by 7.86 percent against the dollar on October 22.
The central bank gave no reason for the latest change, but bankers said it was designed to keep exports competitive.
They said the dollar had strengthened against other major currencies in the past six months, while inflation in Pakistan was running at close to 12 percent a year.
They said with a stubborn trade deficit and a strong dollar in international markets, the central bank had to reassess the value of the rupee to keep Pakistani exports competitive.
The rupee has now lost 14.65 percent of its dollar value since the beginning of fiscal 1996/97 (July-June) compared with a depreciation of 13.2 percent in the year- ago period.

"The rupee had appreciated by five percent since October and there was a need to bring it down to the real effective exchange rate to offset the inflation differential with our trading partners," Raza Mirza, head of research at KASB & Co, said.
He said the depreciation would have little immediate impact on the trade deficit but would help keep the gap from widening.
The consumer price index rose 11.8 percent in March year-on-year from 10.27 percent in March 1996, while the wholesale price index jumped 13.4 percent.
The trade deficit for the first nine months of fiscal 1996/97 had exceeded $2.6 billion.
Sameer Ahmed, head of sales at ING Baring Securities, said the rupee may depreciate by about five percent in the next two to three months.
He said the central bank seemed to be following a crawling peg devaluation policy to avoid any panic in the kerb market and any major impact on the import bill and foreign loan repayments.
The rupee opened 0.05 lower at 41.20 to the dollar in the kerb market following Tuesday's adjustment.
Dealer Ovais Kalia said the central bank was likely to devalue the rupee by another three percent before the June 14 announcement of the 1997/98 budget.
A foreign banker said the rupee's real effective exchange rate had appreciated 9.3 percent between October and March while the nominal effective exchange rate was up 3.9 percent.

He said the central bank was unlikely to go for a one-step devaluation but might slash another two percent off the rupee's value by end-June. He said it would continue the depreciation to keep the rupee close to its real exchange rate.
